title: Texas Tribune's voter guide
description: I designed and developed a new version of the Texas Tribune's voter guide. The ballot lookup feature provides information about each district's population demographics, voter turnout, and the winning margin of the 2020 presidential election, in addition to displaying ballot information based on a user-entered address. Previously, the Tribune used Mapbox for the static maps included in the tool, which proved costly. To reduce expenses, I created the maps without relying on Mapbox. This is one of the most visited pages of the Tribune's website in 2024.

title: How a fraction of voters decide who runs Texas
description: I created a visualization illustrating how primary election voters—a small subset of the entire Texas population—effectively determine the state's elections, using a school of fish as a visual metaphor. The visualization was inspired by the classic children's book Swimmy.

title: General Election results page
description: I designed and developed a map featured on the results page—a cartogram using circles to represent estimated votes, with each circle doubling as a pie chart to display vote breakdowns. This visualization highlights the voter population sizes of each county, which are overlooked in traditional choropleth maps.

title: Which mass shootings are more newsworthy, and why?
description: From 1982 to fall 2021, there were 124 mass shootings in the U.S. I examined the media attention each incident received by counting the number of New York Times articles and their total word count. To conduct this analysis, I developed database query conditions, converted data formats, manually reviewed over 6,000 articles, and analyzed the cleaned data with guidance from researcher Emily Boardman Ndulue. I then visualized the data and developed the web page to present the findings.

title: 9 million Texans voted early in 2024. Here’s how that compares to previous years.
description: Using data scraped from the Texas Secretary of State website, I created charts comparing early voting turnout in the 2024 general election to the two previous presidential elections. Beeswarm charts were used to illustrate turnout across counties, divided by political regions.

title: Texas likely undercounting heat-related deaths
description: I led a statistical analysis estimating heat-related deaths in Texas, using meteorological data and death indexes, with guidance from Ariel Karlinsky, an economist and statistician at Hebrew University. We built a model to predict expected mortality rates under normal conditions and used it to estimate excess deaths on summer days with unusually high heat indexes.

title: Texas weather extremes likely to become normal, scientists say
description: Using precipitation and drought data in Texas, I created maps and charts illustrating the stark divide between East and West Texas—highlighting that the eastern half of the state has experienced above-average rainfall, while the western half has been drier.

title: More oyster harvest areas have been closed in recent years
description: I developed a short-term graphic illustrating the locations and status of oyster harvest areas over the past decade, combining multiple types of charts for a comprehensive view.

title: Many rural counties have no private schools
description: This short-term data visualization highlights the concentration of private schools in urban areas across Texas. Using data from the Texas Private School Accreditation Commission, I verified the existence of each school. The visualization combines a map, bar chart, and waffle chart

title: Texas just recorded its second hottest summer on record
description: As Texas endured weeks of extreme heat, I tracked the number of days temperatures reached or exceeded 100°F in major cities across the state. The data was gathered using NOAA's API endpoints. This visualization combines a line chart and a frequency chart to display the findings.

title: Who’s who in the Ken Paxton impeachment trial, from key participants to potential witnesses
description: Leading up to Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton's impeachment trial, I designed and developed an app highlighting key individuals attending (or not attending) the trial. The main graphic places these individuals within the Texas Senate Chamber, allowing users to click on each person's headshot for additional information and related coverage about them.

title: Climate change has sent temperatures soaring in Texas
description: I conducted a series of data analyses on temperature trends to demonstrate where and how temperatures are rising. I completed the initial analyses and chart designs before starting my maternity leave.

title: Texas heat-related deaths reached a two-decade high in 2022 amid extreme temperatures
description: I created short-term graphics illustrating the increasing number of heat-related deaths in Texas and the locations where these deaths occurred. The second visualization combines a table, heat map, and locator map to comprehensively present the data.

title: Texas’ plan to provide water for a growing population virtually ignores climate change
description: Several graphics in this story illustrate how Texas' water demand is increasing while supplies become less reliable. A choropleth map, paired with proportional bar charts, animates to show projected water resources for each county. Additionally, a scatterplot highlights how rapidly growing counties are expected to experience higher water demand.

title: A celebrated surgeon, a trail of secrets and death
description: I assisted the Spotlight team in analyzing data and identifying key data points. My analysis contributed to their data dashboard as well as the story itself.

title: Food Price Inflation Imposing Heavy Burden on Poorer Countries
description: I developed an interactive chart that allows users to zoom in and out of a scatter plot by scrolling. As readers navigate through different sections of the chart, they gain a deeper understanding of what each data point represents.

title: Ukrainian refugee crisis
description: I visualized data on refugees fleeing Ukraine using dots and animations to represent the movement and distribution of refugees.

title: Migration is Natural
description: My teammates and I analyzed migration data and visualized it using a butterfly metaphor. Each region is represented by a butterfly, which users can click on to explore the path to acquiring citizenship in a country within the selected region.

title: The Astrological Effect on Aviation
description: My teammates and I analyzed the relationship between astrological events and flight accidents and delays, specifically examining the impact of moon phases and Mercury retrograde periods on flight disruptions in the U.S.

title: New ethnic studies requirements mean more lessons on race in Boston classrooms
description: I collaborated with an independent journalist Linda K. Wertheimer for a story about ethnic studies courses in the U.S. Using data from Holyoke Public Schools, I conducted statistical tests to assess the impact of taking ethnic studies courses, with guidance from Arindrajit Dube, a professor at the University of Massachusetts.

title: 74 storms hitting MA: Where they came from and where they were going
description: I created four different types of maps and visualizations illustrating all storms that have directly impacted Massachusetts since the 1850s. I gathered and cleaned the data before importing it into QGIS for geoprocessing and map design. Afterward, I transferred the maps to Illustrator to finalize the static presentation.

title: Moon Junk
description: I found this fascinating data set on manmade materials on the moon, which includes the years and locations where the materials landed, along with the countries responsible for sending them. I mapped these on the moon surface and organized them by year. Additionally, I created

title: Charts show 2020 was not as bad a year for the dairy industry, but the crisis continues
description: I gathered and analyzed data on the dairy industry in Wisconsin before conceptualizing the story, designing, and producing the data visualizations.

title: In Milwaukee, thousands of vacant homes and lots threaten neighborhood safety and property values
description: I analyzed data on vacant properties and developed an interactive map to visualize the findings.

title: Kyoto’s cherry blossoms blooming earlier than ever
description: I visualized the peak bloom dates of cherry blossoms since 812 as a design challenge. I combined a pictogram scatterplot and a histogram, where the scatterplot transitions into the histogram as you scroll. In the smaller version, a bar moves automatically, and users can drag and drop the bar, causing the page to scroll to the corresponding date.

title: Boston Police body cam footage shows confrontations during the protests following the death of George Floyd
description: On May 31, 2020, demonstrations in downtown Boston escalated into violent clashes between protesters and police. I tracked key moments from that night using body camera footage revealed by the news and commentary website, The Appeal.

title: Statistical analysis of cherry blossom's first-blooming date
description: I conducted a range of statistical analyses to examine the trend of first-blooming dates for Japanese cherry blossoms and to test various theories about these dates. The analyses included: a paired t-test comparing actual blooming dates to a 30-year moving average, a one-sample t-test to compare actual blooming dates to expected dates based on a theory, and the geographic mapping of locations where cherry blossoms bloomed on April 1st from the 1950s to the present, among others.

title: Analysis of Sumo Wrestlers
description: I analyzed the tournament ranking tables of Japanese sumo wrestling to identify the characteristics of wrestlers who consistently rank at the top.

title: The life of a caregiver amid the COVID-19 pandemic
description: This multimedia project explores the lives of individuals with dementia and their family caregivers during the coronavirus pandemic. I interviewed two in-home caregivers from the Boston area, and their stories are shared through a combination of text, images, audio files, and videos.
